course.title: HTML Canvas Tutorial
course.description: Learn how to draw graphics, animations, and games using HTML Canvas.

sections.heading: Learn Canvas
paragraphs: The HTML <canvas> element is used to draw graphics on a web page.
The <canvas> element is only a container for graphics. You must use JavaScript to draw graphics.
Canvas supports drawing paths, boxes, circles, text, and images.
Canvas is supported by all major browsers.

sections.heading: What is HTML Canvas?
paragraphs: The HTML <canvas> element is used to draw graphics dynamically using JavaScript.
Canvas itself does not draw anything. JavaScript is required.
Canvas supports drawing shapes, text, images, and animations.

sections.heading: Canvas Capabilities
points: Draw text with or without animation
Used for games and graphical applications

sections.heading: Canvas Example
paragraphs: A basic canvas element looks like this:
sections.code: <canvas id="myCanvas" width="200" height="100"></canvas>

sections.heading: Canvas Explanation
points: The id attribute is required to access the canvas using JavaScript
Width and height define the canvas size
Multiple canvas elements can exist on one page
Canvas has no border by default

sections.heading: Canvas with Border Example
sections.code: <canvas id="myCanvas" width="200" height="100" style="border:1px solid #000000;"></canvas>

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: Canvas must be controlled using JavaScript
Canvas is ideal for animations and games
Canvas graphics do not retain object structure after drawing

sections.heading: Draw on the Canvas With JavaScript
paragraphs: Drawing on the canvas is done using JavaScript.
The canvas is initially blank and requires a script to draw graphics.
To draw, you must access the rendering context of the canvas.

sections.heading: Canvas Example
paragraphs: The following example draws a red rectangle on the canvas:
sections.code:
<canvas id="myCanvas" width="200" height="100" style="border:1px solid black;"></canvas>

<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");
ctx.fillStyle = "red";
ctx.fillRect(0, 0, 150, 75);
</script>

sections.heading: Step 1: Find the Canvas Element
paragraphs: First, you must find the canvas element in the HTML document.
This is done using the getElementById() method.
sections.code: const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");

sections.heading: Step 2: Create a Drawing Object
paragraphs: Next, you need a drawing object.
The getContext() method returns an object with drawing methods.
sections.code: const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

sections.heading: Step 3: Draw on the Canvas
paragraphs: You can now draw on the canvas using JavaScript methods.
The fillStyle property sets the color.
The fillRect() method draws a filled rectangle.
sections.code:
ctx.fillStyle = "red";
ctx.fillRect(0, 0, 150, 75);

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: JavaScript is required to draw graphics
fillStyle can be a color, gradient, or pattern
Canvas is commonly used for games and animations

sections.heading: Canvas Coordinates
paragraphs: The HTML canvas is a two-dimensional grid.
The upper-left corner of the canvas has the coordinates (0,0).
All drawings are positioned relative to this coordinate system.

sections.heading: Draw a Rectangle
paragraphs: To draw a rectangle on the canvas, use the fillRect() method.
The method defines the starting point, width, and height.

sections.heading: Draw a Line
paragraphs: To draw a straight line, use moveTo() and lineTo() methods.
The stroke() method is used to make the line visible.

sections.heading: Draw a Circle
paragraphs: To draw a circle, use the arc() method.
The beginPath() method starts a new drawing path.
The arc() method defines the center, radius, and angle.

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: x-axis moves right, y-axis moves down
stroke() is required to display lines and shapes

sections.heading: Canvas Line Drawing
paragraphs: To draw a line in canvas, several methods are used together.
The line is not drawn until the stroke() method is called.

sections.heading: Draw a Line Example
lineWidth Property
paragraphs: The lineWidth property defines the thickness of the line.
It must be set before calling stroke().

sections.heading: strokeStyle Property
paragraphs: The strokeStyle property defines the color of the line.
It must be set before calling stroke().

sections.heading: lineCap Property
paragraphs: The lineCap property defines how the end of a line looks.
Possible values: butt, round, square.
Default value is butt.

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: stroke() must be called to display the line
beginPath() should be used before drawing a new line

sections.heading: Canvas Fill and Stroke
paragraphs: To define fill-color and outline-color for shapes or objects in canvas, we use the fillStyle and strokeStyle properties.

table.description: Defines the fill color of the object or shape
Defines the outline color of the object or shape

sections.heading: fillStyle Property
paragraphs: The fillStyle property defines the fill color of an object.
The value can be a color name, RGB, HEX, HSL, gradient, or pattern.

sections.heading: strokeStyle Property
paragraphs: The strokeStyle property defines the outline color.
It can use colors, gradients, or patterns.

sections.heading: Combining fillStyle and strokeStyle
paragraphs: Both fill and stroke can be applied together on the same shape.

sections.heading: Using Alpha Channel (Opacity)
paragraphs: Opacity can be added using RGB values with alpha channel.
Alpha values range from 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque).

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: fillStyle sets the inside color of shapes
Both properties can be used together

sections.heading: Canvas Shapes
paragraphs: To draw different shapes that consist of straight lines in canvas, we use several path methods.
These methods allow us to create custom shapes by defining points and connecting them.

table.description: Declares that a new path is about to be drawn
Sets the starting point of the shape
Sets the next point of the shape
Draws the shape using the defined path

sections.heading: Draw a Shape Example
Another Shape Example
strokeStyle Property
paragraphs: The strokeStyle property defines the color of the shape outline.
It must be set before calling the stroke() method.

sections.heading: Shape with strokeStyle
Important Notes
points: beginPath() must be called before drawing a new shape

sections.heading: Canvas Rectangles
paragraphs: The HTML canvas provides three main methods to draw rectangles.
These methods allow you to draw filled, outlined, or defined rectangles.

sections.heading: rect() Method
sections.description: The rect() method defines a rectangle but does not draw it until stroke() or fill() is used.

sections.heading: fillRect() Method
sections.description: The fillRect() method draws a filled rectangle.

sections.heading: fillRect() with Color
strokeRect() Method
sections.description: The strokeRect() method draws an outlined rectangle.

sections.heading: strokeRect() with Color
Multiple Rectangles Example
Important Notes
points: rect() only defines a shape, it does not draw it

sections.heading: clearRect() Method
paragraphs: The clearRect() method is used to clear a rectangular area of the canvas.
The cleared area becomes fully transparent.

sections.heading: Basic Example
sections.description: Draw a filled rectangle and clear a part of it.

sections.heading: Clear Area Outside the Shape
sections.description: The cleared area can extend outside the drawn rectangle.

sections.heading: clearRect() with Stroke Rectangle
sections.description: clearRect() can also clear part of a stroked rectangle.

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: clearRect() removes pixels and makes them transparent
It does not change canvas size
It works on both filled and stroked shapes
Coordinates are relative to the canvas

sections.heading: The arc() Method
paragraphs: The arc() method is used to define a circle.
It draws an arc or a complete circle depending on the angle values.

parameters.name: counterclockwise
parameters.description: Optional. Draws arc counter-clockwise if true

sections.heading: Draw a Full Circle
sections.description: Use startAngle = 0 and endAngle = 2 × Math.PI to draw a full circle.

sections.heading: Draw a Circle with Fill and Stroke
sections.description: Add fill and stroke colors to the circle.

sections.heading: Draw a Half Circle
sections.description: Use Math.PI as the ending angle to draw a half circle.

sections.heading: Arc Angles
points: Angles are measured clockwise by default

sections.heading: Arc with Counterclockwise Direction
sections.description: Set the last parameter to true to draw counterclockwise.

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: stroke() or fill() is required to display it

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Canvas provides methods to draw curved lines.
The most commonly used curve methods are:
arc(), quadraticCurveTo(), and bezierCurveTo().

sections.heading: Quadratic Curve
sections.description: The quadraticCurveTo() method is used to draw a quadratic Bézier curve.

sections.heading: Drawing a Quadratic Curve
Bezier Curve
sections.description: The bezierCurveTo() method is used to draw a cubic Bézier curve using two control points.

parameters.name: cp1x
parameters.description: X-coordinate of the first control point

parameters.name: cp1y
parameters.description: Y-coordinate of the first control point

parameters.name: cp2x
parameters.description: X-coordinate of the second control point

parameters.name: cp2y
parameters.description: Y-coordinate of the second control point

sections.heading: Drawing a Bezier Curve
Key Points
points: stroke() is required to draw the curve

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Gradients allow smooth color transitions in canvas.
Gradients can be applied to shapes, text, and strokes.
Canvas supports two types of gradients: Linear and Radial.

sections.heading: createLinearGradient() Method
sections.description: Defines a linear gradient between two points.

sections.heading: Linear Gradient Example
Vertical Linear Gradient
sections.description: Created by changing y-axis values.

sections.heading: Diagonal Linear Gradient
sections.description: Created by changing both x and y values.

sections.heading: Gradient with Multiple Colors
Fill Circle with Gradient
Fill Text with Gradient
Stroke Text with Gradient
Key Points
points: Gradients can be applied to shapes and text
Linear gradients can be horizontal, vertical, or diagonal

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The createRadialGradient() method is used to define a radial (circular) gradient.
A radial gradient is defined by two circles: a start circle and an end circle.
The gradient spreads from the start circle to the end circle.

sections.heading: Basic Radial Gradient Example
sections.description: Creates a radial gradient with a small inner circle and a large outer circle.

sections.heading: Smaller Radius Gradient
sections.description: Reducing the radius of the end circle makes the gradient smaller.

sections.heading: Moving the Gradient Center
sections.description: Changing the center of the end circle alters the gradient direction.

sections.heading: Multiple Color Stops
sections.description: You can add multiple colors using addColorStop().

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Multiple color stops can be used
Gradients can be applied to shapes and text
createRadialGradient() works with fillStyle and strokeStyle

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Canvas allows drawing text using JavaScript.
The most important properties and methods used for text are:
font – defines font style and size
fillText() – draws filled text
strokeText() – draws outlined text

sections.heading: font Property
sections.description: The font property defines the font size and style used for text.

sections.heading: fillText() Method
sections.description: The fillText() method draws filled text on the canvas.

sections.heading: strokeText() Method
sections.description: The strokeText() method draws outlined text.

sections.heading: Bold and Italic Text
sections.description: Font styles like bold and italic can be added using the font property.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: font property controls size and style
Text can be bold, italic, or both
Canvas text supports colors and gradients

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Canvas allows text coloring using two properties:
fillStyle – sets the fill color of text
strokeStyle – sets the outline color of text

sections.heading: fillStyle Property
sections.description: The fillStyle property defines the fill color of the text.

sections.heading: strokeStyle Property
sections.description: The strokeStyle property defines the outline color of the text.

sections.heading: Fill Text with Gradient
sections.description: Text can be filled with a linear gradient using createLinearGradient().

sections.heading: Outlined Text with Gradient
sections.description: Gradient can also be applied to outlined text using strokeStyle.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Gradients can be used as text colors
Works with both fillText() and strokeText()
Supports RGB, HEX, HSL, and gradients

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Canvas text alignment is controlled using two properties:
textBaseline – controls vertical alignment of text
textAlign – controls horizontal alignment of text

sections.heading: textBaseline Property
sections.description: The textBaseline property defines the vertical alignment of the text.

sections.heading: textAlign Property
sections.description: The textAlign property defines the horizontal alignment of text.

sections.heading: Center Text Example
sections.description: This example centers text both vertically and horizontally.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Both properties must be set before drawing text
Useful for centering text precisely on canvas

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.description: Canvas shadows are created using four properties.

sections.heading: shadowColor Property
sections.description: Defines the color of the shadow. Default is transparent black.

sections.heading: Shadow on Text
sections.description: Shadow applied to filled and stroked text.

sections.heading: shadowBlur Property
sections.description: Defines the amount of blur applied to the shadow.

sections.heading: shadowOffsetX Property
sections.description: Controls horizontal distance of shadow.

sections.heading: shadowOffsetY Property
sections.description: Controls vertical distance of shadow.

sections.heading: Key Notes
points: Shadows work on shapes, text, and strokes
Shadow properties must be set before drawing
Negative values move shadow left or upward

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.description: The drawImage() method is used to draw images onto the canvas.
methods: drawImage(image, sx, sy, swidth, sheight, dx, dy, dwidth, dheight)

sections.heading: drawImage(image, dx, dy)
sections.description: Draws an image at a specific position on the canvas.

sections.heading: drawImage(image, dx, dy, dwidth, dheight)
sections.description: Draws and scales the image to a specified width and height.

sections.heading: drawImage(image, sx, sy, swidth, sheight, dx, dy, dwidth, dheight)
sections.description: Clips a portion of the source image and draws it on the canvas.

sections.heading: Key Notes
points: Image must be fully loaded before drawing
Used for games, image editors, and animations
Works with , video, or another canvas

canvas-transformations.title: Canvas Transformations
canvas-transformations.description: Canvas transformations allow you to move, rotate, scale, and skew drawings on the canvas.

sections.heading: translate()
sections.description: Moves the canvas origin to a new position.

sections.heading: rotate()
sections.description: Rotates the canvas by an angle in radians.
sections.note: Use (Math.PI / 180) * degrees to convert degrees to radians.

sections.heading: scale()
sections.description: Scales objects horizontally and vertically.

sections.heading: transform()
sections.description: Applies transformation using a matrix.

sections.heading: resetTransform()
sections.description: Resets the transformation matrix to default.

sections.heading: setTransform()
sections.description: Resets transformation and applies a new one.

notes: Useful for animations and graphics manipulation

canvas-clipping.title: Canvas Clipping
canvas-clipping.description: The clip() method is used to limit the drawing area of the canvas. Anything drawn outside the clipping region will not be visible.

parameters.fillRule: Defines how to determine inside and outside areas (nonzero | evenodd)
parameters.path: A path used as the clipping region

sections.heading: Basic Clipping
sections.description: Creates a circular clipping region and draws shapes inside it.

sections.heading: Triangle Clipping
sections.description: Creates a triangular clipping region.

sections.heading: Image Clipping
sections.description: Clips an image inside a circular region.

sections.heading: Clipping with Path2D (evenodd)
sections.description: Creates a hole using evenodd rule.

sections.heading: Clipping with Path2D (nonzero)
sections.description: Uses default nonzero rule without hole.

notes: Clipping affects everything drawn after clip()
Clipping region cannot be undone unless canvas is reset
Use save() and restore() to control clipping
evenodd rule creates holes inside clipping paths

canvas-compositing.title: Canvas Compositing
canvas-compositing.description: The globalCompositeOperation property controls how new drawings are combined with existing canvas content.

modes.name: source-over
modes.description: Draws new shapes on top of existing content (default behavior).

modes.name: source-out
modes.description: Draws new shapes only where they do NOT overlap existing content.

modes.name: destination-over
modes.description: Draws new shapes behind the existing content.

modes.name: destination-atop
modes.description: Keeps existing content where it overlaps new shapes.

modes.name: copy
modes.description: Only the new shape is visible; old content is removed.

modes.name: multiply
modes.description: Multiplies pixel colors to create a darker effect.

notes: Useful for masking, blending, and visual effects
Reset by setting globalCompositeOperation back to 'source-over'
